properties.description: Up to 90% of people living with dementia will experience distressed behaviour as a result of unmet needs, but the majority of it is preventable. We’ve built the first AI tool that predicts distressed behaviour in dementia care, before it happens, giving carers real-time & evidence-based support to prevent distress, prevent crises, reduce medication, and meet people's needs effectively.
properties.how_does_your_company_use_innovation__th:
We’re combining behavioural science with machine learning to do something that hasn’t been done before in dementia care: predict distressed behaviour before it happens.

Instead of waiting for things to go wrong and reacting in crisis, Less Distress is an app that uses real-world care data to spot early warning signs and guide carers in real time. It’s personalised, preventative, and based on the science of why behaviour happens in the first place, something most systems completely ignore.

Our innovation isn’t just in the tech, it’s in the model. We’re giving frontline carers access to the kind of behavioural insight that’s usually locked away in specialist services, and doing it in a way that’s fast, affordable, easy to use on the job, and a globally scalable solution.
properties.how_does_your_product_contribute_to_a_he:
Less Distress is about making things better for everyone involved in dementia care: The person, the carer, and the family.

All behaviour happens for a reason. In dementia, that reason is often an unmet need, but it’s very hard for carers to understand what the need is without proper training (which they very rarely receive). We help carers see what the behaviour is trying to say, so they can respond in a way that meets the need, not just manages the reaction.

When carers can predict distress before it happens, they can step in early and calmly, rather than reacting in crisis. Right now, when distressed behaviour is difficult for carers to support with, people are given unlicensed antipsychotics just to keep them sedated even though the side effects can be devastating: sedation, stroke, and death. It’s not person-centred care, it’s damage control.

Less Distress helps change that. We give carers real tools, grounded in behavioural science, so they can reduce medication, prevent placement breakdowns, and support the person effectively. That means more dignity, more calm, and more moments where people feel understood, not lost.

When it feels like no one cares...emwillcare
properties.name: emwillcare
properties.please_expand:
I’m not just looking for money, I’m looking for real partnership that brings not just funding, but support, mentorship, and guidance from people who’ve done this before and can help me take what I’ve started and turn it into something huge.

The AI company we’re working with built our prototype for free, and they’re still developing with us at no cost, because they believe in what we’re doing. It's the same with our marketing support. People are giving their time and skills because they’ve seen the impact that I have as a behaviour analyst, and they believe in me to make it happen.

In July, I’ll be pitching to investors for the first time at an Alzheimer’s Society event. I know my field, I’m one of only 80 behavioural analysts in the world who specialise in dementia. What I need now is someone who can help me build this into a service that’s available to everyone who needs it at a devastating time in their life.

I’m here to deliver and I’m the right person for this job. I’ll be the best entrepreneur you’ve ever worked with. I care for the people I help and want to make their lives better on a wider scale than I can do in-person. I make change happen, I’ve done it all my life (I started my other business 4 years ago, the first behavioural consultancy business in the UK for dementia care). And now I’m ready to do it on a much bigger scale to help millions of people.
properties.what_best_describes_your_stage_of_busine: I have a business that I want to scale
properties.what_is_your_usp__what_makes_you_differe:
There are currently no competitors in the field. I’m one of only 80 behaviour analysts in the whole world specialising in dementia care, and I’ve spent years working directly with carers, trying to stop distress before it spirals into crisis. However, there is only so many people I can help in-person.

'Less Distress', by emwillcare takes my knowledge and expertise and is the first tool that actually predicts distressed behaviour using behavioural science and AI, not just tracking what’s already gone wrong, but helping carers know what to do next, in real time. This isn’t just innovation, it’s a lifeline for caregivers.

We are supported by the Alzheimer's Society Launchpad programme, and Business Wales Accelerator Growth Programme.
properties.where_is_your_business_based_: UK but wanting to scale to US

structured_data.executive_summary: Revolutionising Dementia Care with Behavioural Science & AI. Predict Distress. Prevent Crisis. Support Carers. LESS DISTRESS is an AI-powered behavioural support platform for dementia carers that automates the process of assessing and preventing distressed behaviours for people with dementia.
structured_data.problem_statement: Dementia care costs the UK £34.7 billion/year, expected to hit £94.1 billion by 2040. Key issues include: 1) Increased health & social care costs due to inability to support behaviours resulting from dementia, 2) 30% average staff churn rate with onboarding costs of £3642 per staff member who rarely receive behavioural support or training, 3) Unlicensed antipsychotic drug use with nasty side effects for behavioural issues.
structured_data.solution: An AI-powered digital healthcare platform that automates the process of assessing and preventing distressed behaviours for people with dementia. Caregivers log distressed behaviours and AI-driven behavioural science identifies triggers & patterns, providing personalised, actionable strategies.
structured_data.product_service_description: LESS DISTRESS is a digital healthcare platform where caregivers log distressed behaviours and AI-driven behavioural science identifies triggers & patterns. A recommendation engine provides personalised, actionable strategies based on evidence-based scientific principles to reduce distress, improve care, and prevent unnecessary medication.
structured_data.market_size_opportunity: Dementia care costs the UK £34.7 billion/year and is expected to hit £94.1 billion by 2040, representing a significant market opportunity.
structured_data.team: Dr Emma Williams is mentioned as part of the team. The company appears to be called EmWillCare.
structured_data.traction_milestones: The company has Advance Assurance in place for SEIS & EIS. Their roadmap includes: Build MVP digital platform, Run pilot in care homes, AI model refinement using real-world data, Position for larger NHS & care provider contracts.
structured_data.go_to_market_strategy: The roadmap suggests a phased approach: 1) Build MVP digital platform, 2) Run pilot in care homes, 3) AI model refinement using real-world data, 4) Position for larger NHS & care provider contracts.

founder_profiles.name: Dr Emma Williams
founder_profiles.background_summary: Dr Emma Williams is a highly experienced professional in dementia care, with over 27 years in the field and a PhD in Psychology from Bangor University. She is the founder of EmWill Care, a company focused on revolutionising dementia care by integrating behavioural science with smart technology, specifically through their 'Less Distress' tool. She also founded PACT (Positive Ageing Consultancy & Training). Her leadership experience includes her current founder role and previous roles such as Director of Training for North Wales Regional Partnership Board and providing bespoke behavioural consultancy. Dr Williams is currently participating in accelerator programs with the Alzheimer's Society and Business Wales, indicating active development and validation of her venture. Her public content and posts demonstrate thought leadership and a strong personal mission to improve dementia care.

previous_companies.description: Founded and led a consultancy focused on positive ageing and training in dementia care.
Led training initiatives and provided strategic direction for dementia care programs.

public_speaking_or_content.title: Showcasing 'Less Distress' at London Tech Week
Collaboration with Alzheimer's Society Innovation Team

investment_criteria_assessment.assessment_summary: From research_prospect_tool output: Dr Emma Williams and EmWill Care are a strong fit for Flight Story's investment criteria, with clear industry relevance (tech-enabled dementia care), mission alignment (improving quality of life), a compelling and innovative solution, relevant founder experience, impressive sector background, and evidence of strategic thinking and thought leadership.

company_profile.description: emwillcare is a healthtech company focused on transforming dementia care by providing evidence-based, innovative solutions that empower caregivers and improve the quality of life for individuals living with dementia. The company delivers digital tools and consultancy to reduce distress, minimize medication reliance, and enhance care management.
key_products_services: Less Distress (digital tool for predicting and preventing distress in dementia care)
Behavioural science-based consultancy and training for care providers
company_profile.business_model: B2B SaaS and consultancy—emwillcare provides digital tools and training services to care homes, commissioners, and organizations supporting people with dementia.
company_profile.target_customer: Care home owners, commissioners, and organizations seeking cost-effective, evidence-based solutions to improve dementia care quality and outcomes.
company_profile.mission_statement: To transform dementia care by ensuring individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support, while empowering their caregivers with effective, evidence-based strategies.

market_analysis.industry_overview: Health technology (health-tech) refers to the application of organized knowledge and skills in the form of devices, medicines, vaccines, procedures, and systems developed to solve health problems and improve quality of life. The industry encompasses a broad range of technologies, including digital health, telemedicine, electronic health records, wearable devices, health apps, and advanced medical devices. Health-tech aims to enhance healthcare delivery, improve patient outcomes, and increase efficiency in healthcare systems.
market_analysis.target_market_segment: The health-tech market targets healthcare providers (hospitals, clinics, physicians), payers (insurance companies), patients/consumers, pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and government health agencies. Segments include telehealth users, remote patient monitoring, digital therapeutics, AI-driven diagnostics, and health data management.
key_market_trends: Accelerated digital transformation and adoption of telemedicine and virtual care
Integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in diagnostics and patient management
Growth in wearable health devices and remote patient monitoring
Expansion of personalized and precision medicine
Increased focus on data interoperability and health information exchange
Rising consumerization of healthcare (direct-to-consumer health apps and services)
Adoption of cloud-based healthcare IT solutions
Growing use of 3D bioprinting and regenerative medicine technologies
market_analysis.competitor_landscape_summary: The global health-tech market is highly fragmented, with a mix of established medical device and IT companies, digital health startups, and technology giants. Key players differentiate through innovation, scale, and integration capabilities. The market is witnessing significant investment, M&A activity, and the emergence of unicorn startups. Market share is distributed among large multinational corporations and fast-growing digital health companies.

competitors.name: Siemens Healthineers AG
strengths: Comprehensive portfolio in imaging, diagnostics, and digital health

competitors.name: Medtronic
weaknesses: Exposure to regulatory and reimbursement risks
Competition from emerging digital health startups

competitors.name: Epic Systems Corporation
strengths: Market leader in electronic health records (EHR)
Large installed base in hospitals and health systems

competitors.name: Apple
strengths: Integration of health features in consumer devices (Apple Watch, HealthKit)

competitors.name: Tempus AI, Inc.
strengths: AI-driven precision medicine and data analytics
Rapid innovation in genomics and oncology
weaknesses: Reliance on data access and integration

company_competitive_advantages: Proprietary AI and data analytics platforms
Integration of consumer and clinical health data
Strong partnerships with healthcare providers and payers
Focus on patient-centric and personalized care
barriers_to_entry: Complex and fragmented regulatory requirements across regions
High capital and R&D investment needed for product development and compliance
Lengthy and resource-intensive approval processes for medical technologies
Vendor lock-in and integration challenges with existing healthcare IT systems
Market acceptance and stakeholder buy-in (providers, patients, payers)
Established incumbents with significant market power
market_analysis.market_timing_assessment: Favorable; the market is in a strong growth phase with high investment, rapid innovation, and increasing adoption of digital health solutions globally.
market_analysis.regulatory_environment: The global health-tech regulatory environment is highly complex and varies by country and region. Key regulatory bodies include the FDA (US), EMA (Europe), and WHO, each with stringent guidelines for medical devices, digital health, and data privacy. Recent years have seen new regulations and harmonization efforts, but companies must navigate a patchwork of laws, including GDPR (Europe) for data protection and HIPAA (US) for health data privacy. Compliance is resource-intensive, and regulatory arbitrage is sometimes used to accelerate market entry. Ongoing changes in digital health regulation require companies to remain agile and well-informed.

investment_assessment.overall_criteria_summary: emwillcare is a healthtech company focused on dementia care, led by Dr Emma Williams, an experienced founder and thought leader in the field. The company is highly mission-aligned, offers an innovative and meaningful solution, and the founder has strong relevant experience and evidence of exceptional strategic thinking. However, the company does not fit Flight Story's core focus industries (Media, Brand, Tech, or Creator Economy), as it is primarily a healthcare/healthtech play.
key_risk_factors: Does not fit Flight Story's core industry focus (healthtech vs. media/brand/tech/creator economy)
Early stage with no revenue or significant traction yet
Highly regulated market with complex compliance requirements
Potentially long sales cycles (B2B, NHS, care providers)
Competitive landscape includes large, well-funded incumbents in healthtech
key_opportunities: Addresses a massive, growing, and under-served problem in dementia care
First-mover advantage in AI-driven behavioural support for dementia
Strong founder credibility and sector expertise
Backed by reputable accelerators (Alzheimer’s Society, Business Wales)
Potential for significant impact on quality of life for patients and caregivers
Scalable SaaS/consultancy model with global applicability
investment_assessment.investment_thesis_summary: emwillcare is a mission-driven healthtech startup with a unique AI-powered solution for predicting and preventing distress in dementia care. The founder, Dr Emma Williams, brings deep sector expertise, prior founder experience, and thought leadership. The solution addresses a real and growing problem, with strong early validation from accelerators and sector partners. However, the opportunity does not align with Flight Story's core industry focus, which is a gating issue for investment.
investment_assessment.potential_return_profile: If successful, emwillcare could capture a significant share of the rapidly growing digital health and dementia care market, with potential for high impact and attractive returns. However, the early stage, regulatory hurdles, and long sales cycles increase risk and may delay returns.
investment_assessment.deal_terms_summary: Raising £250-500k at a sub-£1m valuation; 100% founder-owned; SEIS/EIS advance assurance in place. No prior equity investment.
recommended_next_steps: Decline investment due to lack of industry fit with Flight Story's mandate.
Optionally, refer to healthtech-focused investors or funds with a mandate for healthcare innovation.
Monitor for future pivots or partnerships that might bring the business into closer alignment with Flight Story's focus areas.
